name: Fred Schepisi
description: Fred Schepisi's diverse body of work connects to acclaimed local productions, westerns and Hollywood favourites.

key_work.title: Spotlights: Fred Schepisi
key_work.brief_description: An Australian film director, producer and screenwriter. His credits include The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith (1978), Plenty (1985), Roxanne (1987), Six Degrees of Separation (1993), Mr. Baseball (1992) and Last Orders (2001). Fred talks about his love for the craft and offers a perspective on violence.

constellations_primary.name: Fred Schepisi
constellations_primary.description: Fred Schepisi's diverse body of work connects to acclaimed local productions, westerns and Hollywood favourites.

start.title: Spotlights: Fred Schepisi
start.brief_description: An Australian film director, producer and screenwriter. His credits include The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith (1978), Plenty (1985), Roxanne (1987), Six Degrees of Separation (1993), Mr. Baseball (1992) and Last Orders (2001). Fred talks about his love for the craft and offers a perspective on violence.

constellations_primary.name: Fred Schepisi
constellations_primary.description: Fred Schepisi's diverse body of work connects to acclaimed local productions, westerns and Hollywood favourites.

end.title: The Devil's Playground
end.creator_credit: Fred Schepisi and Feature Film House Productions
end.brief_description: The Devil’s Playground is a 1976 Australian drama film written, produced and directed by Fred Schepisi. It is a semi-autobiographical film which tells the story of a boy growing up and going to school in a Catholic juniorate administered by De La Salle Brothers.

constellations_other.name: Fred Schepisi
constellations_other.description: Fred Schepisi's diverse body of work connects to acclaimed local productions, westerns and Hollywood favourites.

links.description: Acclaimed Australian director Fred Schepisi’s first feature was The Devil’s Playground, a semi-autobiographical film about a boy growing up in a Catholic school. The film explores with the “myriad of ways men deal with sexual repression in the Catholic church”, according to film critic Luke Buckmaster.

start.title: The Devil's Playground
start.creator_credit: Fred Schepisi and Feature Film House Productions
start.brief_description: The Devil’s Playground is a 1976 Australian drama film written, produced and directed by Fred Schepisi. It is a semi-autobiographical film which tells the story of a boy growing up and going to school in a Catholic juniorate administered by De La Salle Brothers.

constellations_other.name: Fred Schepisi
constellations_other.description: Fred Schepisi's diverse body of work connects to acclaimed local productions, westerns and Hollywood favourites.

end.title: The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith
end.creator_credit: Brian Kavanagh, Fred Schepisi and The Film House
end.brief_description: Based on the Thomas Keneally novel, this is the fictionalised story of Jimmy Governor, who, in 1901 went on a rampage killing numerous white settlers. Deft characterisation and ironic detail combine to paint a bleak portrait of a bitterly racist society emerging as a federated nation. Starring Tommy Lewis in the title role with co-stars Ray Barrett and Jack Thompson.

constellations_other.name: Fred Schepisi
constellations_other.description: Fred Schepisi's diverse body of work connects to acclaimed local productions, westerns and Hollywood favourites.

links.description: After his debut, Schepisi directed the controversial The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith. The film follows an Indigenous man (Tom E Lewis), who murders a white family and goes into hiding. Though acclaimed at the time, it raises questions of whether white filmmakers should tell Indigenous stories.

start.title: The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith
start.creator_credit: Brian Kavanagh, Fred Schepisi and The Film House
start.brief_description: Based on the Thomas Keneally novel, this is the fictionalised story of Jimmy Governor, who, in 1901 went on a rampage killing numerous white settlers. Deft characterisation and ironic detail combine to paint a bleak portrait of a bitterly racist society emerging as a federated nation. Starring Tommy Lewis in the title role with co-stars Ray Barrett and Jack Thompson.

constellations_other.name: Fred Schepisi
constellations_other.description: Fred Schepisi's diverse body of work connects to acclaimed local productions, westerns and Hollywood favourites.

end.title: Sweet Country
end.creator_credit: Warwick Thornton, Heather Wallace, David Jowsey, Greer Simpkin, Bunya Productions, Tony Cronin, David Tranter and Steven McGregor
end.brief_description: It’s 1929 on the vast, desert-like, Eastern Arrernte Nation lands that are now known as the Central Australian outback. Sam Kelly, a middle-aged Aboriginal man, works the land of a kind preacher, Fred Smith. After an ill-tempered bully arrives in town and Kelly kills him in self-defence, he and his wife go on the run as a posse gathers to hunt him down.

constellations_primary.name: Sweet Country
constellations_primary.description: Warwick Thornton’s feature film Sweet Country is based on the story of Wilaberta Jack, which was told to sound recordist David Tranter by his grandfather and translated into storyboards.

constellations_other.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_other.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

constellations_other.name: The Australian industry
constellations_other.description: Though our local industry is small, our impact is huge.

constellations_other.name: Crime doesn't pay
constellations_other.description: Ned Kelly's famous armour has appeared in many films, but the criminal myth speaks to how audiences have always been captivated by true-crime stories, from the beginning of cinema to today.

constellations_other.name: Fred Schepisi
constellations_other.description: Fred Schepisi's diverse body of work connects to acclaimed local productions, westerns and Hollywood favourites.

constellations_other.name: Native Tongue
constellations_other.description: The lead single off her album of the same name, 'Native Tongue' saw artist Mo'Ju explore cultural identity through music, movement and striking visuals.

constellations_other.name: Outlawed
constellations_other.description: From The Story of the Kelly Gang to Sweet Country, this Constellation explores bushrangers, samurai and bandits.

constellations_other.name: Inspired design and costume sketches
constellations_other.description: Costume designers Edie Kurzer and Alice Babidge have worked on some of the most acclaimed Australian and international films and TV, joining the ranks of fellow Australians creatives.

links.description: Warwick Thornton’s Sweet Country has a similar premise: an Indigenous man kills a white stockman and goes on the run. However, Sam (Hamilton Morris) is a sympathetic character who kills only out of self-defense and Thornton, as a First Peoples director, is better suited to tell the story.

start.title: The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith
start.creator_credit: Brian Kavanagh, Fred Schepisi and The Film House
start.brief_description: Based on the Thomas Keneally novel, this is the fictionalised story of Jimmy Governor, who, in 1901 went on a rampage killing numerous white settlers. Deft characterisation and ironic detail combine to paint a bleak portrait of a bitterly racist society emerging as a federated nation. Starring Tommy Lewis in the title role with co-stars Ray Barrett and Jack Thompson.

constellations_other.name: Fred Schepisi
constellations_other.description: Fred Schepisi's diverse body of work connects to acclaimed local productions, westerns and Hollywood favourites.

end.title: Barbarosa
end.creator_credit: Fred Schepisi, Paul N. Lazarus III, Alliance, Incorporated Television Company (ITC) and William D. Wittliff
end.brief_description: Karl Westover, an inexperienced farm boy, runs away after unintentionally killing a neighbor, whose family pursues him for vengeance. He meets Barbarosa, a gunman of near-mythical proportions, who is himself in danger from his father-in-law Don Braulio, a wealthy Mexican rancher.

constellations_other.name: Fred Schepisi
constellations_other.description: Fred Schepisi's diverse body of work connects to acclaimed local productions, westerns and Hollywood favourites.

links.description: American audiences interpreted The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith as a western, which led to Schepisi being offered the chance to direct Barbarosa, starring Willie Nelson and Gary Busey, which kicked off Schepisi’s Hollywood career.

start.title: Empire Falls
start.creator_credit: Donna Zakowska, Fred Schepisi, William Teitler, Aspetuck Productions, HBO Films, Marc Platt Productions, Stuart Wurtzel and Richard Russo
start.brief_description: The humorous, poignant story of a declining New England town and its inhabitants, whose lives are deeply rooted in and influenced by the Knox River and its vacant mills, their class differences, and ghosts of the past.

constellations_other.name: Fred Schepisi
constellations_other.description: Fred Schepisi's diverse body of work connects to acclaimed local productions, westerns and Hollywood favourites.

end.title: Nobody's Fool
end.creator_credit: Robert Benton, Joseph G. Aulisi, Arlene Donovan, Scott Rudin, Capella International, Cinehaus, Paramount Pictures and David Gropman
end.brief_description: Sully is a rascally ne’er-do-well approaching retirement age. While he is pressing a worker’s compensation suit for a bad knee, he secretly works for his nemesis, Carl, and flirts with Carl’s young wife Toby.

constellations_other.name: Fred Schepisi
constellations_other.description: Fred Schepisi's diverse body of work connects to acclaimed local productions, westerns and Hollywood favourites.

links.description: Empire Falls was the last time that legendary actor Paul Newman appeared on-screen. Philip Seymour Hoffman, who appears in Empire Falls, was also in Nobody’s Fool with Newman. Both are based on novels by Richard Russo.

start.title: Nobody's Fool
start.creator_credit: Robert Benton, Joseph G. Aulisi, Arlene Donovan, Scott Rudin, Capella International, Cinehaus, Paramount Pictures and David Gropman
start.brief_description: Sully is a rascally ne’er-do-well approaching retirement age. While he is pressing a worker’s compensation suit for a bad knee, he secretly works for his nemesis, Carl, and flirts with Carl’s young wife Toby.

constellations_other.name: Fred Schepisi
constellations_other.description: Fred Schepisi's diverse body of work connects to acclaimed local productions, westerns and Hollywood favourites.

end.title: Driving Miss Daisy
end.creator_credit: Bruce Beresford, Alfred Uhry, Elizabeth McBride, Lili Fini Zanuck, Richard D. Zanuck, Robert Doudell, Majestic Films International, The Zanuck Company, Warner Bros. Pictures, Bruno Rubeo and John P. Mesa
end.brief_description: The story of an old Jewish widow named Daisy Werthan and her relationship with her black chauffeur, Hoke. From an initial mere work relationship grew in 25 years a strong friendship between the two very different characters in a time when those types of relationships where shunned.

constellations_other.name: Fred Schepisi
constellations_other.description: Fred Schepisi's diverse body of work connects to acclaimed local productions, westerns and Hollywood favourites.

links.description: After 60-year career, another legendary actor, Jessica Tandy, last appeared on-screen in Nobody’s Fool. Like Newman, Tandy was an Oscar winner, receiving the Academy Award for her performance in Driving Miss Daisy, directed by Schepisi’s contemporary, Australian Bruce Beresford.

start.title: Barbarosa
start.creator_credit: Fred Schepisi, Paul N. Lazarus III, Alliance, Incorporated Television Company (ITC) and William D. Wittliff
start.brief_description: Karl Westover, an inexperienced farm boy, runs away after unintentionally killing a neighbor, whose family pursues him for vengeance. He meets Barbarosa, a gunman of near-mythical proportions, who is himself in danger from his father-in-law Don Braulio, a wealthy Mexican rancher.

constellations_other.description: Fred Schepisi's diverse body of work connects to acclaimed local productions, westerns and Hollywood favourites.

end.title: Empire Falls
end.creator_credit: Donna Zakowska, Fred Schepisi, William Teitler, Aspetuck Productions, HBO Films, Marc Platt Productions, Stuart Wurtzel and Richard Russo
end.brief_description: The humorous, poignant story of a declining New England town and its inhabitants, whose lives are deeply rooted in and influenced by the Knox River and its vacant mills, their class differences, and ghosts of the past.

constellations_other.name: Fred Schepisi
constellations_other.description: Fred Schepisi's diverse body of work connects to acclaimed local productions, westerns and Hollywood favourites.

links.description: After over 20 years directing dramas, comedies and even a sci-fi film, Schepisi turned his attention to TV with the 2005 miniseries Empire Falls, which won a Golden Globe for Best Miniseries or Television Film and received seven Emmy nominations.
